title: Good cameras but glitchy software
text:
I have three cameras in my frail 85-year-old mom‚Äôs apartment so I can monitor her safety ‚Äî especially during the hours when her paid caregivers are not present.  Glitchy software has me shopping for replacements.  Was really hoping that when Nokia bought out the original manufacturer, Whithings, things would improve fast. Have indeed seen some marginal improvements ‚Äî but far fewer than I was hoping for. With each new app update I still have my fingers crossed (especially since these Whithings cameras cost twice as much as the competing models back when I first bought them at the Apple Store and then at Home Depot). 

PROS: Elegant camera design blends in gracefully with my mom‚Äôs decor and doesn‚Äôt make her feel like I have ‚Äúspycams‚Äù everywhere.  Cameras are very easy to install and ‚Äî in theory ‚Äî very easy to monitor in my iphone.  Resolution, color, sound, and playback features are all quite useful. It‚Äôs great that you can add (and view) multiple cameras in multiple rooms. The nightvision, audio, air quality, and alert features all work just fine. 

CONS: My disappointment and frequent frustration are all due to the extemely glitchy and unreliable software.  Often when I first open the app the software says ‚Äúyour cameras are unavailable.‚Äù  Yet I have learned that simply rebooting the app once or twice usually fixes the problem. So, in fact, the cameras really ARE available...eventually. At other times only two out of three cameras function. But never the same two. 

Worst of all:  Even after all three cameras boot up the picture will often ‚Äúfreeze‚Äù for long periods of time completely. Sometimes switching to another camera ‚Äúfixes‚Äù the freeze. But often not. Sometimes closing the app completely (ugh, yes, again) fixes this freeze problem too. And sometimes not. This is of course especially maddening if my mom‚Äôs health is especially fragile that night, such that I am truly relying on the camera system to monitor her every move carefully. 

FIXES:  Since I was a very ‚Äúearly adopter‚Äù I had to buy one more camera to replace the very first one I had purchased (which the company prior to Nokia, Whithings, flat out refused to replace). The darn thing just stopped working completely, and their tech help yielded no results even after many attempts. 

Next I upgraded the wifi speed in my mom‚Äôs hom thinking maybe that was the root of the problem. Now all other apps I run on my mom‚Äôs wifi ‚Äî including streaming Netflix etc. ‚Äî work flawlessly. But the darn Nokia cams Still Freeze Up or Fail to open at all just as frequently as ever. 

Then I decided maybe the download speed on my iphone and ipad at home was too slow. Yet here again I can stream whole movies on my iphone and ipad without any trouble at all ‚Äî so why then are my (extremely expensive) Nokia Home Cams still freezing up and/or failing to connect on a regular basis?

title: Not ready for prime time
text:
There are missing features that were/are marketed and currently being shown on their FAQ, manuals and marketing material that are missing. Why use it as a selling point and not bother to deliver on it?? These include temp and humidity, audio playback, video playback, none of which I've seen on the app. 

The home diary shows that you can click on an audio event to play back what ever audio triggered an alarm. That is not the case, right now it's just a time stamp showing you how long audio was heard and that's it. 

The motion detection is similarly ridiculous, it is simply a time lapse of several snap shots, hardly a video. More than a handful of the motion I intentionally triggered resulted in a time lapse video of nothing since it was either too slow or took pictures of when I was in and out of the video in too rapid of a succession. I set up the camera in my bedroom to try to catch my dog in the act of knocking the trash can down, it caught nothing since she did it so fast. The time lapse vid was two still photos long with the can knocked down for both pics.

Another annoying thing was that I had trouble going from full screen live mode back to the home diary view. You're suppose to be able to tap on the live view video a few times so it will minimize and go back, but most of the time it was just frustrating and would simply ignore the command. Maybe I had the gesture wrong since it seemed to work only about 60% of the time. 

Most importantly, within a 16 hour time frame, I had received online and offline triggers in rapid succession both while I was trying to view live video while I was at home and away, and also while the app was closed. It would go off and on just randomly while I know my home network is solid and has a very dependable high speed connection. 

On the same vein privacy mode would also go on and off with out me ever turning the wood cover to trigger it.

For 200$ Withings released such a poor product full of bugs and missing features that are all over their marketing material.

Overall, I was disappointed and returned it under 24 hours of receiving it in the mail. Thank goodness I ordered it through Apple since it seems like Withings customer support is slow to respond.

title: Crappy software, crappy support
text:
I've had the camera for about 2 weeks and like everyone is saying - the app has much to be desired from. 
The camera and the idea behind it is genius. But the buggy software, the frustrating customer support and the expensive subscription plans ruin the whole experience. 

First, the software. Since day 1 I have had audio problems coming from the Withings camera on my 6s+. The sound is always jarred and sounds like C3PO, you can't understand anything. It is not hardware related problem, because it plays fine on my iPad. 
The app crashes a lot on iPad Air when double-tapping to zoom in portrait orientation. 
There was a strange problem with auto night mode. When morning came, the camera live feed displayed everything colored in blue. Like there were 4-5 horrid blue Instagram filters stacked on. I barely managed to fix it by setting night mode to OFF one night and on the next day - to AUTO. 

Second, the customer support. 
For a company charging so much for home and health/fitness devices, you've gotta fix your website and email support. I've searched for hours how to contact customer support via email and how to send feedback about the Apple Watch app. 
When I finally was reached by email support, it took around 20 emails back and forth with days between them in waiting time in order for the 'specialist' to understand my issue and what I have did to troubleshoot. And let me say I'm not a noob, I have a significant software and hardware knowledge in almost every IT aspect.

Last, but not least, I want to express my sincere frustration from the 'service' Withings offers.
After charging 200 euro for a camera, they want additional 8/20 euro per month for video cloud recording. If you want ANY recorded video, you have to subscribe. The free basic plan offers ONLY GIF segments (for the last 2 days) when movement/sound is detected. The problem is that if a burglar enters your home, his face may or MAY NOT be recorded in the GIF segment with the basic plan. Let's say you are abroad, you don't have mobile data connection everywhere. Then you don't get notification that someone is robbing you. Therefore you can't alarm the police. When you get home on the next day your Withings camera may have recorded around 4-5 frames with the burglar and they almost definitely will not have caught the burglar's face. 
I know that cloud storage costs money, but does it cost that much as Whitings wants? Why not offering the basic plan with Dropbox/iCloud Drive support? I'm already paying Apple 3$/month for 200 GB. Whitings, why you want to charge me additional 8‚Ç¨/$ for a service which should have been free in the first place? I believe everyone expected this functionality to be free on the device out of the box.

NETGEAR PL1200-100PAS 1200Mbps Powerline
and now the camera and app work great, everything as advertised. I'm using as a baby monitor and wifi is (arguably) not good for babies any way, so it's a win win situation.
